awd_titl_txt: Workshop on Technology for Automated Capture of Diet, Nutrition, and Eating Behaviors in Context
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports a workshop on computational and engineering approaches to measuring eating behavior and nutrition. The workshop brings together investigators, policy makers and biomedical researchers to develop a multidisciplinary future in nutrition and eating behavior assessment. To date, the biomedical community is still measuring nutrition and eating behavior using either 24-hour recall or having people come to the hospital so that food can be rationed and measured precisely. The use of technology is limited and the computing and engineering community have struggled with targeting the correct behaviors (e.g., food purchases versus time chewing) and units of measures (micronutrients versus time chewing). Thus, the tools being developed do not match the needs and does not advance the scientific community as a whole.  To develop effective models and methods, ultimately requires the collaboration of diverse researchers who normally do not talk together nor attend similar conferences nor read the same academic literature. 

Eating behavior and nutrition has long been a focus of the computing and engineering communities because they are rich with exciting technical challenges. For example, understanding food intake at a granular level will likely require advances in computer vision, optics and/chemical engineering.  Thus, this workshop will bring together those who are building new methods and tools with those who will use them to create a research plan for the future of these diverse research groups.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE TRUSTEES OF COLUMBIA UNIVERSITY IN THE CITY OF NEW YORK

por.por_cntn:
The major goals of this set of workshops were to explore new directions for research in computing technologies for diet monitoring that synergistically blend different technical modalities (sensors, video, audio, chemical analysis, etc.) in a way bounded by scientific requirements for research in nutrition, and by realistic expectations of user burden associated with using these technologies.

The workshops’ activities focused primarily on the fundamental scientific challenges that need to be resolved in order to produce transformative new tools for this applied science. In particular, a key strategy is to bring basic science disciplines together to discuss their various dietary implementations, with a particular focus on facilitating discussion around accuracy, precision, and usability issues as bound by the use-cases each group is working within.

The first three workshops in this series included provocative talks coupled with breakout sessions to expand on these presentations. Participants also were able to view these talks and participate in discussions asynchronously (via Slack). Based on these activities, participants were invited to submit proposals (individually or in teams) that propose new ideas and technologies for measuring diet, nutrition, and eating behaviors. All workshop presentations were recorded and are available to the general public via the workshop website: https://sites.google.com/eng.ucsd.edu/diet-tech-nsf-workshop/home). During the final session, teams were asked to present their ideas and, subsequently, notification of award was made for three $15K seed projects, chosen from among the teams that participated.

Each of the three projects produced notable outcomes.

Project 1, titled “Detection of Eating through CGMs and Wearables” (Investigators: Bobak Mortazavi, Jessilyn Dunn, Garrett Ash, Temiloluwa Prioleau) focused on context-aware eating recognition for just-in-time logging. The investigators developed a custom application for collecting and identifying important contextual moments in free-living environments including: sleeping, eating, working, commuting, and exercise. The application was used to collect data for 8 participants over a 10-day period. These data was then used to develop a hierarchical, ensemble machine learning method that predicted periods of eating by voting across each sensing modality’s estimation of eating identified moments and durations of eating periods with increased accuracy and timing, improving eating detection from using CGM data alone with an improvement in meal intake estimation timing of 20 minutes from CGM data alone.

Project 2, titled Food And Nutrition by Camera Image (FANCI) Analysis: An Innovative Technology For Food and Nutrient Intake Measurement Using Image Spectrum (Investigators: Walter Bialkowski, S. Iqbal Ahamed, Jacqueline Jones, Praveen Madiraju, Daniel Pinto, and Zeno Franco) developed a categorization model and an android app to predict what type of food is found in a certain image. To train this model to perform on this specific task, the investigators used a collection of food images and their class labels from the Food101 image dataset and non-food images from the TinyImageNet200 dataset. Combining these datasets, there was over 100,000 images labeled as one of 101 different classes of food, or a non-food class.

Project 3, titled Exploring Trade-offs in the Design Space of Human-Centered Semi-Automated Food Journaling (Investigators: Daniel Epstein and Edison Thomaz), led to deeper understanding of people’s anticipated preferences around different techniques for semi-automated dietary monitoring through a survey with 600 potential users. Specifically, the project learned that wearable ADM sensors that have fewer physical, social, and privacy burdens were more acceptable, as were prompts more relevant to food journaling goals. Non-facial sensors were viewed as much more acceptable, but this tends to trade off detection performance.

 

 


Last Modified: 09/08/2022
Modified by: Lena Mamykina
